xxl.core.cursors
Class AbstractCursor<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
AdvTupleCursor, AggregateGrouper, Aggregator, ArrayCursor, ChannelCursor, ContinuousRandomNumber, CrossTableCursor, DBScan, DiscreteRandomNumber, EmptyCursor, EnumerationCursor, Enumerator, FileNameCursor, Flatten, HashGrouper, IndexedNestedLoopsJoin, Inductor, InputStreamCursor, Intersection, IterableCursor, IteratorCursor, Mapper, Merger, MergeSorter, MSJ.MSJSorter, NearestNeighborQuery, NestedLoopsDifference, NestedLoopsDistinct, NestedLoopsGrouper, NestedLoopsIntersection, NestedLoopsIntersection, NestedLoopsJoin, ObjectToBlockCursor, Permutator, PostponeUpdatesCursor, QueryCursor, QueueCursor, RandomRectangle, Repeater, ReplacementSelection, ResetableCursor, ResettableSequentializer, ResultSetMetaDataCursor, RTreeJoin, Sequentializer, SortBasedDifference, SortBasedDistinct, SortBasedDivision, SortBasedGrouper, SortBasedIntersection, SortMergeJoin, TeeCursor, Tree.Query
public abstract class AbstractCursor<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Cursor<E>

An abstract cursor implements the methods of the interface Cursor and is useful in those cases when you produce elements and want to return them by a cursor. For example consider a query-operation on an index structure that returns an iteration over its results. It is sufficient then to create an abstract cursor and implement the abstract methods hasNextObject and nextObject.
Both methods are protected ones that are only called internally by the abstract cursor whenever a new result is requested on that cursor. The contract of these methods is that:

  • hasNextObject determines whether the iteration has more elements.
  • nextObject computes the next object in the iteration.
Important: In order to guarantee a certain semantics, an extension of an AbstractCursor has to ensure that a call of hasNext always returns false after the first time false is delivered. Thus, it should not be possible to receive an element by calling hasNext and next() at a later point in time, if hasNext returned false before (even if the underlying data structure received a new element meanwhile).

Example usage: The cursor DiscreteRandomNumber produces a certain number (noOfObjects) of random integer objects by calling Random.nextInt(). Therefore RandomIntegers extends AbstractCursor and the implementation of its abstract methods is as follows: 

   protected boolean hasNextObject() {
       return noOfObjects == -1 || noOfObjects > 0;
   }
 
   protected Object nextObject() {
       if (noOfObjects > 0)
           noOfObjects--;
       return new Integer(random.nextInt(maxValue));
   }
This means, as long as noOfObjects > 0 holds (or noOfObjects == -1 for an infinite number of random integer objects), the cursor has more elements and the next element will be set to new Integer(random.nextInt(maxValue)).

Note, that the abstract methods of the cursor interface are implemented in this class, i.e., an abstract cursor already provides the mechanisms that are required for its functionality.

  • An abstract cursor provides a hasNext/next mechanism guaranteeing a call to the method hasNext before the next element in the iteration will be accessed, i.e., there will be at least on call to the abstract method hasNextObject before the second abstract method nextObject is called.
  • It also provides an open/close mechanism. Due to the decoupling of a cursor's construction and its open phase, it must be guaranteed that a cursor is opened before it is accessed. For this reason the hasNext method checks whether the cursor has already been opened and opens it explicitly if not. When a cursor has been closed, its elements cannot be accessed any more, i.e., a call to the methods peek and next will throw an exception rather than returning an element. Also a closed cursor cannot be re-opened by a call to its open method. Both methods (open and close are implemented idempotent, i.e., consecutive calls to this methods will have the same effect as a single call.

Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open files, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public void open() {
       if (!isOpened)
           isOpened = true;
   }

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<E>

close

public void close()
Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close files, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public void close() {
       if (!isClosed) {
           hasNext = false;
           computedHasNext = false;
           isValid = false;
           isClosed = true;
       }
   }

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<E>

isClosed

public boolean isClosed()
Returns true if the cursor has been closed.

Returns:
true if the cursor has been closed.

hasNext

public final boolean hasNext()
                      throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

This operation is implemented idempotent, i.e., consequent calls to hasNext do not have any effect.

Important: In order to guarantee a certain semantics, an extension of an AbstractCursor has to ensure that a call of hasNext always returns false after the first time false is delivered. Thus, it should not be possible to receive an element by calling hasNext() and next() at a later point in time, if hasNext() returned false before (even if the underlying data structure received a new element meanwhile).

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public final boolean hasNext() throws IllegalStateException {
       if (isClosed)
           throw new IllegalStateException();
       if (!isOpened)
           open();
       if (!computedHasNext) {
           hasNext = hasNextObject();
           computedHasNext = true;
           isValid = false;
           assignedNext = false;
       }
       return hasNext;
   }

Specified by:
hasNext in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.

hasNextObject

protected abstract boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

This abstract operation should implement the core functionality of the hasNext method which secures that the cursor is in a proper state when this method is called. Due to this the hasNextObject method need not to deal with exception handling.

Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.

next

public final E next()
             throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                    java.util.NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public final E next() throws IllegalStateException,
                                NoSuchElementException {
       if (!computedHasNext)
           hasNext();
       if (!hasNext)
           throw new NoSuchElementException();
       if (!assignedNext) {
           next = nextObject();
           assignedNext = true;
       }
       hasNext = false;
       computedHasNext = false;
       isValid = true;
       return next;
   }

Specified by:
next in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

nextObject

protected abstract E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

This abstract operation should implement the core functionality of the next method which secures that the cursor is in a proper state when this method is called. Due to this the nextObject method need not to deal with exception handling.

Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

peek

public final E peek()
             throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                    java.util.NoSuchElementException,
                    java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without proceeding the iteration (optional operation). After calling peek the returned element is still the cursor's next one such that a call to next would be the only way to proceed the iteration. But be aware that an implementation of this method uses a kind of buffer-strategy, therefore it is possible that the returned element will be removed from the underlying iteration, e.g., the caller can use an instance of a cursor depending on an iterator, so the next element returned by a call to peek will be removed from the underlying iterator which does not support the peek operation and therefore the iterator has to be wrapped and buffered.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors. After calling the peek method a call to next is strongly recommended.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public final E peek() throws IllegalStateException,
                                NoSuchElementException,
                                UnsupportedOperationException {
       if (!supportsPeek())
           throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
       if (!computedHasNext)
           hasNext();
       if (!hasNext)
           throw new NoSuchElementException();
       if (!assignedNext) {
           next = nextObject();
           assignedNext = true;
       }
       isValid = true;
       return next;
   }

Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
java.util.NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsPeek

public final boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

     public final boolean supportsPeek() {
         return true;
     }

Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

remove

public void remove()
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the cursor (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and removes the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and remove the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Note, that this operation is optional and does not work for this cursor.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public void remove() throws IllegalStateException,
                               UnsupportedOperationException {
       if (!supportsRemove())
           throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
       if (!isValid)
           throw new IllegalStateException();
       hasNext = false;
       computedHasNext = false;
       isValid = false;
       assignedNext = false;
   }

Specified by:
remove in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor<E>
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsRemove

public boolean supportsRemove()
Returns true if the remove operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public boolean supportsRemove() {
       return false;
   }

Specified by:
supportsRemove in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
true if the remove operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

update

public void update(E object)
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the last element returned by the cursor in the underlying data structure (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and updates the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and update the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Note, that this operation is optional and does not work for this cursor.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public void update(E object) throws IllegalStateException,
                                       UnsupportedOperationException {
       if (!supportsUpdate())
           throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
       if (!isValid)
           throw new IllegalStateException();
       hasNext = false;
       computedHasNext = false;
       isValid = false;
       assignedNext = false;
   }

Specified by:
update in interface Cursor<E>

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the update method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the cursor.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public boolean supportsUpdate() {
       return false;

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and does not work for this cursor.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public void reset() throws IllegalStateException,
                              UnsupportedOperationException {
       if (!supportsReset())
           throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
       hasNext = false;
       computedHasNext = false;
       isValid = false;
       assignedNext = false;
   }

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<E>
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public boolean supportsReset() {
       return false;
   }

Specified by:

true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.
